repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes 2 issues:
1. `int` literals being coerced to Python objects got the integer passed instead of a Python pointer.
2. It failed to use cached Python integer constants (because coercion nodes got in the way).

comment_data.body: I added a little bit of annotation typing here, since I think it probably is somewhere where it makes it clearer. It's pretty tangential to the bug fix though so could be dropped.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15221,11 +15221,12 @@ class AssignmentExpressionNode(ExprNode):
     subexprs = ["rhs"]
     child_attrs = ["rhs", "assignment"]  # This order is important for control-flow (i.e. xdecref) to be right
 
-    is_temp = False
-    assignment = None
-    clone_node = None
+    is_temp: bool = False
+    rhs: ExprNode
+    assignment: SingleAssignmentNode
+    is_literal_assignment: bool = False

comment_data.body:
Do we need to wrap the nodes at this early stage, or can we postpone it until `analyse_types()`, to see if we actually need to do it?
Also, would it help to move the ownership into the assignment node at this stage, and take back the RHS reference from there in `analyse_types()`?

I'm just trying to think of ways to avoid the back and forth un-wrapping into auxiliary nodes that are only *sometimes* needed and could possibly *only* be done in the respective cases.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15221,11 +15221,12 @@ class AssignmentExpressionNode(ExprNode):
     subexprs = ["rhs"]
     child_attrs = ["rhs", "assignment"]  # This order is important for control-flow (i.e. xdecref) to be right
 
-    is_temp = False
-    assignment = None
-    clone_node = None
+    is_temp: bool = False
+    rhs: ExprNode
+    assignment: SingleAssignmentNode
+    is_literal_assignment: bool = False
 
-    def __init__(self, pos, lhs, rhs, **kwds):
+    def __init__(self, pos, lhs: NameNode, rhs: ExprNode, **kwds):
         super().__init__(pos, **kwds)
         self.rhs = ProxyNode(rhs)
         assign_expr_rhs = CloneNode(self.rhs)

comment_data.body:
I find this ordering a little clearer.
```suggestion
                self.rhs = self.rhs.arg  # take out of ProxyNode
                self.assignment.rhs = copy.copy(self.rhs)  # replace CloneNode with copy
                self.is_literal_assignment = True
```
Also, something like `self.assignment_is_independent` or "…_separate" might catch the intention a bit better.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15268,7 +15269,9 @@ def analyse_types(self, env):
                 # This is a special case of https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4146
                 # TODO - once that's fixed general revisit this code and possibly
                 # use coerce_to_simple
-                self.assignment.rhs = copy.copy(self.rhs)
+                self.assignment.rhs = copy.copy(self.rhs.arg)
+                self.rhs = self.rhs.arg  # take out of ProxyNode
+                self.is_literal_assignment = True

comment_data.body: I think I've refactored it to defer it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15221,11 +15221,12 @@ class AssignmentExpressionNode(ExprNode):
     subexprs = ["rhs"]
     child_attrs = ["rhs", "assignment"]  # This order is important for control-flow (i.e. xdecref) to be right
 
-    is_temp = False
-    assignment = None
-    clone_node = None
+    is_temp: bool = False
+    rhs: ExprNode
+    assignment: SingleAssignmentNode
+    is_literal_assignment: bool = False
 
-    def __init__(self, pos, lhs, rhs, **kwds):
+    def __init__(self, pos, lhs: NameNode, rhs: ExprNode, **kwds):
         super().__init__(pos, **kwds)
         self.rhs = ProxyNode(rhs)
         assign_expr_rhs = CloneNode(self.rhs)

comment_data.body:
Are we actually sure of the type of `self.assignment`? Transforms may replace the assignment node with something different, depending on what kind of assignment it is. It apparently needs to be something that has a `.rhs` attribute (because otherwise the code would fail), but that's it, really, AFAICT.

That's one of the problems I have with the current typing discussion – even if the concrete annotation is correct when it is written, it may change behind our backs later. And that would be totally ok in most cases, because it is what transforms are there for.

As a totally sidetracked BTW: what happens if we nest assignment expressions, like `(a := (b := x))`? Is that special in any way? Can it be special? Should it be special?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15221,27 +15222,29 @@ class AssignmentExpressionNode(ExprNode):
     subexprs = ["rhs"]
     child_attrs = ["rhs", "assignment"]  # This order is important for control-flow (i.e. xdecref) to be right
 
-    is_temp = False
-    assignment = None
-    clone_node = None
+    is_temp: bool = False
+    rhs: Optional[ExprNode] = None
+    assignment: SingleAssignmentNode

comment_data.body:
You can test multiple paths. Or did you chose this form intentionally?
```suggestion
@cython.test_fail_if_path_exists(
    "//CloneNode",
    "//CoercionNode",
)
```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -40,6 +40,30 @@ def optimize_literals1():
     return (x := 10)
 
 
+@cython.test_fail_if_path_exists("//CloneNode")
+@cython.test_fail_if_path_exists("//CoercionNode")
+def optimize_literals1_typed_int():
+    """
+    There's a small optimization for literals to avoid creating unnecessary temps
+    >>> optimize_literals1_typed_int()
+    10
+    """
+    x: cython.int = 5
+    return (x := 10)
+
+
+@cython.test_fail_if_path_exists("//CloneNode")
+@cython.test_fail_if_path_exists("//CoercionNode")

comment_data.body:
Reassigning `self` (and then continuing to do our normal business) is generally risky because the node might actually have been replaced by the `analyse_types()` call. If you assume that it wasn't, then that seems a good thing to assert here, at least.
```suggestion
            if self.rhs is None:
                self = self.analyse_types(env)
                assert isinstance(self, AssignmentExpressionNode)
```

The cleaner alternative would be to not call `analyse_types()` again (note that we're in `coerce_to()` here, which is only used after analysing a node) but to extract the parts of it that we need here (there's probably a concrete reason why you call it here) into a separate method, without the possibility of a `self` replacement, and call that from both places.

Also, you probably don't want the `rhs` to end up double wrapped in `CloneNode`s, do you?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15284,7 +15292,13 @@ def analyse_types(self, env):
         return self
 
     def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
+        if self.assignment_is_independent:
+            # rhs and assignment don't share a node, so just behave normally
+            self.rhs = self.rhs.coerce_to(dst_type, env)
+            return self
         if dst_type == self.assignment.rhs.type:
+            if self.rhs is None:
+                self = self.analyse_types(env)

comment_data.body: I've just replaced it with an assert that that rhs isn't None.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15284,7 +15292,13 @@ def analyse_types(self, env):
         return self
 
     def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
+        if self.assignment_is_independent:
+            # rhs and assignment don't share a node, so just behave normally
+            self.rhs = self.rhs.coerce_to(dst_type, env)
+            return self
         if dst_type == self.assignment.rhs.type:
+            if self.rhs is None:
+                self = self.analyse_types(env)

comment_data.body:
I think in this case I'm fairly sure it isn't replaced, but of course that isn't future proof

Given these annotations aren't enforced, I guess the question is: is a (possible) slightly wrong annotation worse than a (possibly) slightly wrong comment? Or is the improved editor hints helpful enough to justify it.

I guess the danger is that they do eventually end up enforced somehow...

------------------

> As a totally sidetracked BTW: what happens if we nest assignment expressions, like (a := (b := x))? Is that special in any way? Can it be special? Should it be special?

It works. It isn't special. For pyobject assignment expressions it generates slightly more reference counting than it needs to. There's a comment further down saying

> ```
> # TODO - there's a missed optimization in the code generation stage
> # if self.rhs.arg is temp: an incref/decref pair can be removed
> # (but needs a general mechanism to do that)
> ```

I think if that were fixed then nested assignment expressions would be close to optimal. So I don't think they need to be special, but they could be improved along with some other things.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15221,27 +15222,29 @@ class AssignmentExpressionNode(ExprNode):
     subexprs = ["rhs"]
     child_attrs = ["rhs", "assignment"]  # This order is important for control-flow (i.e. xdecref) to be right
 
-    is_temp = False
-    assignment = None
-    clone_node = None
+    is_temp: bool = False
+    rhs: Optional[ExprNode] = None
+    assignment: SingleAssignmentNode

commit.message:
Fix code-generation with walrus+literals

Fixes 2 issues:
1. `int` literals being coerced to Python objects got the integer
   passed instead of a Python pointer.
2. It failed to use cached Python integer constants (because
   coercion nodes got in the way).
Call the right function in the tests

Try to refactor assignment expression clone/proxynode creation

Defer until needed

title: Fix code-generation with walrus+literals
